sentences: Fiona Apple McAfee-Maggart (born September 13, 1977) is an American singer-songwriter.
section: N/A

sentences: She has released five albums from 1996 to 2020, which have all reached the top 20 on the U.S. Billboard 200 chart.
section: N/A

sentences: Apple has received numerous awards and nominations, including three Grammy Awards, two MTV Video Music Awards, and a Billboard Music Award.
section: N/A

sentences: The youngest daughter of the actor Brandon Maggart, Apple was born in New York City and was raised alternating between her mother's home in New York and her father's in Los Angeles.
section: N/A

sentences: Classically trained on piano as a child, she began composing her own songs when she was eight years old.
section: N/A

sentences: Her debut album, Tidal, containing songs written when she was 17, was released in 1996 and received a Grammy Award for Best Female Vocal Rock Performance for the single "Criminal".
section: N/A

sentences: She followed with When the Pawn... (1999), produced by Jon Brion, which was also critically and commercially successful and was certified Platinum.
section: N/A

sentences: For her third album, Extraordinary Machine (2005), Apple again collaborated with Brion and began recording the album in 2002.
section: N/A

sentences: However, Apple was reportedly unhappy with the production and opted not to release the record, leading fans to protest Epic Records, erroneously believing that the label was withholding its release.
section: N/A

sentences: The album was eventually re-produced without Brion and released in October 2005.

sentences: The album was certified Gold, and nominated for a Grammy Award for Best Pop Vocal Album.

sentences: In 2012, she released her fourth studio album, The Idler Wheel..., which received critical praise and was followed by a tour of the United States and was nominated for the Grammy Award for Best Alternative Music Album in 2013.

sentences: Apple's fifth studio album, Fetch the Bolt Cutters, was released in 2020 to widespread acclaim, earning two Grammy Awards: Best Alternative Music Album and Best Rock Performance for the lead single "Shameika".

== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Fiona Apple was born Fiona Apple McAfee-Maggart on September 13, 1977, in New York City to singer Diane McAfee and actor Brandon Maggart, who met when both were cast in the Broadway musical Applause.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Her father is from Tennessee, and through him, Apple has Melungeon ancestry.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Her maternal grandparents were dancer Millicent Green and big band vocalist Johnny McAfee.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Her sister, Amber, sings cabaret under the stage name Maude Maggart, and actor Garett Maggart is her half brother.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Apple grew up in Morningside Gardens in Harlem with her mother and sister, but spent summers with her father in Los Angeles, California.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Apple was classically trained on piano as a child, and began composing her own pieces by the age of eight.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: When learning to play piano, she would often take sheet music and translate guitar tablature into the corresponding notes.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Apple later began to play along with jazz standard compositions after becoming proficient, through which she discovered Billie Holiday and Ella Fitzgerald, who became major influences on her.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Since childhood, Apple has struggled with obsessive-compulsive disorder, depression, and anxiety, and has also been diagnosed with complex post-traumatic stress disorder.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: At age 12, she was raped outside the apartment she shared with her mother, step-father, and sister in Harlem.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: She subsequently developed an eating disorder, purposely slimming her developing body, which she saw as "bait" for potential predators.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: "I definitely did have an eating disorder," she recalled.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: "What was really frustrating for me was that everyone thought I was anorexic, and I wasn't.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: I was just really depressed and self-loathing."
section: == Early life ==

sentences: She also described how her OCD had a significant impact on her eating habits, by requiring food to be a certain color or shape.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: After the rape, Apple began attending Model Mugging classes, practicing self-defense, but continued to suffer panic attacks while walking home from school, which led to her relocating to Los Angeles to live with her father for one year.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: In Los Angeles, Apple attended Alexander Hamilton High School for her second year.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: In a 2000 interview, Apple stated that, despite speculation from journalists, she did not write songs about the trauma surrounding her rape: "It doesn't get into the writing.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: It's a boring pain.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: It's such a fuckin' old pain that, you know, there's nothing poetic about it."
section: == Early life ==
== Career ==

sentences: Career ==
section: == Career ==

sentences: Apple was introduced to the music industry in 1994, when she gave a demo tape containing the songs "Never Is a Promise", "Not One of Those Times", and "He Takes a Taxi" to her friend who was the babysitter for music publicist Kathryn Schenker.
section: == Career ==

sentences: Schenker then passed the tape along to Sony Music executive Andy Slater.
section: == Career ==

sentences: Apple's abilities captured his attention, and Slater signed her to a record deal.
section: == Career ==

== Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: In 1996, Apple's debut album, Tidal, was released by Work Records and Columbia Records.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: The record was largely inspired by Apple's recent breakup with her first boyfriend.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: The album sold 2.7 million copies and was certified three times Platinum in the U.S. "Criminal", the third single, became a hit and the song reached the Top 40 on the U.S. Billboard Hot 100.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: The song's controversial Mark Romanek-directed music video played on MTV.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: Other singles from Tidal included "Shadowboxer", "Sleep to Dream", and "Never Is a Promise".
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: Apple accepted the MTV Video Music Award for Best New Artist at the 1997 MTV Video Music Awards for her song "Sleep to Dream", during her acceptance speech she said:
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: This world is bullshit.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: And you shouldn't model your life—wait a second—you shouldn't model your life about what you think that we think is cool and what we're wearing and what we're saying and everything.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: Go with yourself.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: Apple responded to criticisms of her acceptance speech in Rolling Stone in January 1998, stating, "When I have something to say, I'll say it."
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: During this period, Apple also covered the Beatles' "Across the Universe" and Percy Mayfield's "Please Send Me Someone to Love" for the soundtrack of the film Pleasantville.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: She later canceled the last 21 dates on a tour in support of her album due to "personal family problems".
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: In 1997, Apple met director Paul Thomas Anderson during a photoshoot, and the two began a relationship that lasted several years.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: Apple's second album, When the Pawn..., was released in 1999.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: Its full title is a poem Apple wrote after reading letters that appeared in Spin regarding an article that had cast her in a negative light in an earlier issue.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: The title's length earned it a spot in the Guinness Book of Records for 2001.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: However, as of October 2007, it no longer has the longest album title, as Soulwax released Most of the Remixes, a remix album whose title surpasses When the Pawn's length by 100 characters.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: When the Pawn was cultivated during Apple's relationship with film director Paul Thomas Anderson.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: When the Pawn, which was produced by Jon Brion, used more expressive lyrics, experimented more with drum loops, and incorporated both the Chamberlin and drummer Matt Chamberlain.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: The album received a positive reception from publications such as Rolling Stone.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: It did not fare as well commercially as her debut, though it was an RIAA-certified Platinum album and sold one million copies in the U.S.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: The album's lead single, "Fast as You Can", reached the top twenty on Billboard's Modern Rock Tracks chart and became Apple's first Top 40 hit in the UK.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: The videos for two follow-up singles, "Paper Bag" and "Limp" (directed by then-boyfriend Anderson), received very little play.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: In a February 2000 set hampered by equipment issues to 3,000 audience members at the New York City Roseland Ballroom, a frustrated Apple left the stage without returning.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: Her performance saw Apple appearing distraught at the sound quality, apologizing numerous times for the sound and crying.
section: == Career == | === 1996–2001: Tidal and When the Pawn... ===

sentences: After completing a concert tour in support of her second album in 2000, Apple relocated to Los Angeles, where she still resides as of 2020.

sentences: Apple's third album, Extraordinary Machine, was originally produced by Jon Brion.
section: == Career == | === 2002–2010: Extraordinary Machine and release delays ===

sentences: In spring 2002, Apple and Brion, her longtime friend and producer on When the Pawn, met for their weekly lunch meeting.
section: == Career == | === 2002–2010: Extraordinary Machine and release delays ===

sentences: Brion reportedly "begged" Apple to make another album.
section: == Career == | === 2002–2010: Extraordinary Machine and release delays ===

sentences: Apple agreed, and Brion went to Apple's label, Epic Records, with strict stipulations (including no deadline), which the label eventually agreed to.
section: == Career == | === 2002–2010: Extraordinary Machine and release delays ===

sentences: Recording sessions began in 2002, at Ocean Way studios in Nashville, Tennessee, but later moved to the Paramour Mansion in Los Angeles.
section: == Career == | === 2002–2010: Extraordinary Machine and release delays ===

sentences: Work on the album continued until 2003, and in May of that year it was submitted to Sony executives.
section: == Career == | === 2002–2010: Extraordinary Machine and release delays ===

sentences: In 2004 and 2005, tracks were leaked on the Internet in MP3 format and played on U.S. and international radio.
section: == Career == | === 2002–2010: Extraordinary Machine and release delays ===

sentences: Subsequently, MP3s of the entire album went online.
section: == Career == | === 2002–2010: Extraordinary Machine and release delays ===

sentences: Although a website distributing the album was quickly shut down, it soon reached P2P networks and was downloaded by fans.
section: == Career == | === 2002–2010: Extraordinary Machine and release delays ===

sentences: A fan-led campaign supported the album's official release.
section: == Career == | === 2002–2010: Extraordinary Machine and release delays ===

sentences: Mike Elizondo, who had previously played bass on Pawn, was brought back as co-producer to complete the tracks he had begun with Brion and Apple.
section: == Career == | === 2002–2010: Extraordinary Machine and release delays ===

sentences: Spin later reported the following: "Fans erroneously thought that Apple's record label, Epic, had rejected the first version of Extraordinary Machine... in reality, according to Elizondo, Apple was unhappy with the results, and it was her decision to redo the record, not her label's."
section: == Career == | === 2002–2010: Extraordinary Machine and release delays ===

sentences: In August 2005, the album was given an October release date.

sentences: Production had been largely redone "from scratch" by Elizondo and was co-produced by Brian Kehew.
section: == Career == | === 2002–2010: Extraordinary Machine and release delays ===

sentences: Two of the 11 previous leaked tracks were relatively unchanged, and one new song was also included.
section: == Career == | === 2002–2010: Extraordinary Machine and release delays ===

sentences: Despite suggestions that the album had caused a rift between Brion and Apple, they regularly perform together at Largo, a club in Los Angeles, including a joint appearance with Elizondo on bass just before the news broke of an official release.

sentences: Philanthropy ==

sentences: On June 30, 2019, Apple pledged to donate two years' worth of earnings from TV and movie placements of her song "Criminal" to the While They Wait fund, which assists refugees with basic necessities, immigration fees and legal services.
